bibl.title: Letter from Oliver L. Pothier to Joseph H. White, May 26, 1923

div1.p: Pothier reports on the reactions obtained from the sera of the cases of yellow fever seen in Bucaramanga.

div1.head: Letter from Oliver L. Pothier to Joseph H. White, May 26, 1923
div1.opener:
COPY
I. H. B.
Columbia
Baranquilla May 26th, 1923.
Dr. J. H. White
Chief of the Commission
sent to Colombia.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
I wish to report as follows on the reactions obtained from the sera
of the cases of Yellow fever that we saw in Bucaramanga.

The first case was that of Esteban Figueroa, who had been sick for six
days and who presented the cardinal symptoms of yellow fever, in the most typical
and classical way. This case was seen by the Commission on May the first 1923
and his blood taken the same morning. On account of the impossibility of obtain-
ing guinea pigs that day a reaction was made in vitro, using equal parts of serum
and a culture of Leptospira Icteroides, (Nugochi) (Arias Strain). The specimen
was observed for a period of half an hour to an hour and gave what appeared to
be a complete agglutination, Two days after May 3/23 having obtained guinea pigs
Pfeiffer test was made and it gave a positive reaction with equal parts of serum
and culture of Leptospira Icteroides, (Nugochi, Arias Strain)

On May 1st, 1923, we saw another case, Cristobal Rueda, a mild case
who was then without fever, after being sick three days. His blood was taken on
the same date and submitted also to a reaction in vitro, it being impossible on
that date to obtain any guinea pigs. It gave also a positive reaction with a
mixture of equal parts of serum and culture of Leptospira Icteroides (Nugochi,
Arias Strain) On May 3/23 having obtained guinea pigs Pfeiffer test was made and
it gave a positive reaction. The reaction of this serum were weaker and appeared
after a longer period of time, not before forty-five minutes and were observed for
one hour and a half.

The Arias Strain was used because these cultures were the best the others
presenting contemminations. The difficulties of transportations that we had to
reach Bucaramanga and the transportation on mule back of these cultures by one of
us who had them continually with him did not prevent the action of excessive heat on
them and also the more or less jarring in riding, may have accounted for the con-
tamination of several of the cultures, the Arias Strain, were all free from con-
taminations.

On may 4th, 1923, we went to the College San Pedro, where several cases
had appeared in February. We saw two of these cases one a very severe case Father
Hidalgo, and the other one a mild case, one of the brothers of the order, Jesuits.
Their blood was taken and carried to Bogota, in sealed ampoules, that is the serum.
These were subjected to Pfeiffer reaction in Bogota at the Laboratory of Drs
Samper and Martinez. They gave positive reactions with equal parts of serum and
cultures of Leptospira Icteroides. (Arias Strain.)

The cross reaction Leptospira Icterohaemorrhagica, were made with the
serum obtained from Figueroa, and from Father Hidalgo, only. These Pfeiffer
reactions with Leptospira Icterohaemorrhagica were negative, the reaction was
made one part of serum to fifty parts of culture.

We would have made a series of reaction at different titers had it not
been the difficulties that we had in obtaining the proper light and other ac-
cessories. We deemed however that these reactions were sufficiently clear to es-
tablish a positive diagnosis, they were seen by all of the commission and Drs
Samper and Martini, in whose Laboratory we were working.

I wish to state that I owe many thanks to Dr. McCormick in Bucaramanga
for the use of his laboratory and apparatus, and his kind assistance in my work
and in procuring guinea pigs, in Bogota, to Drs Samper and Martiniez who put their
(Report of Dr. Pothier) Cont'd
(2)
exceptionally well equipped laboratory at my disposal and that of the commission,
and furnished all the guinea pigs that I needed.
